memory: Oh, hey! Yeah, I’m a Computer Science major—fourth year now, so it’s basically crunch time for me. My schedule this semester is absolutely killer but in a good way, I guess. Yeah, I’m a Computer Science major—fourth year now, so it’s basically crunch time for me. My schedule this semester is absolutely killer but in a good way, I guess. I’m finally taking those higher-level courses that seemed so far off when I was just a freshman. It’s kind of surreal to be at this stage, you know? It feels like only yesterday I was sitting in an intro class learning about simple data structures, but now I’m all in with complex algorithmic concepts, advanced system design, and stuff even I never thought I’d be tackling, like quantum computing basics.Let me break it down for you. My favorite class this semester is definitely Advanced Algorithms. I’m a huge fan of theory when it connects directly to real-world problem-solving—like, how do we optimize pathfinding in large networks, or what’s the fastest way to handle huge datasets with minimal time complexity? That kind of problem is super fascinating to me. We’ve been diving into everything from dynamic programming approaches to approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems. It really messes with your head sometimes, but in a good, challenging way. Our professor is great; she’s got a knack for explaining these dizzying concepts in a really intuitive manner. She’ll put up a problem on the board—something you’d think is impossible to solve in polynomial time—and then she’ll show us a strategy to at least approximate a solution. Every time I leave that class, my brain’s buzzing.Aside from that, I’m taking a Distributed Systems course(CS 2631), which is probably the second hardest. I mean, wow, it’s a lot of reading, a lot of group discussions, and we’re working on a major project that’s supposed to simulate a decentralized file storage system. The group project is definitely an adventure. We have to collaborate with folks who have different coding styles and sometimes different ideas of what the final product should look like. But that’s also the beauty of it, right? In a real-world setting, you’re never working in a vacuum. You have to be able to integrate your code with others’ and handle everything from concurrency issues to node failures gracefully. It’s nerve-wracking at times—like last week, I spent hours troubleshooting a weird bug that turned out to be a single misplaced bracket in one of the config files. But once we got that fixed and everything ran smoothly, it was this huge sense of accomplishment.I'm also doing an elective in Game Design—yes, it counts toward my major if I combine it with a certain set of other classes. To be honest, I’ve always been a gamer at heart, so this was a must-take. The professor is actually from the industry; he worked on a couple of indie games that got some decent traction. We’re learning about basic 2D and 3D engines, how to implement physics, and even a bit of user experience design. It’s unbelievably fun because every assignment is super creative. Last time, I had to design a mini-game based on a labyrinth concept, and it was all about balancing the difficulty curve so players wouldn’t get frustrated and quit. Getting that design right was tricky, but it was also rewarding to see it come together.Oh! And one class I might’ve regretted signing up for at first but now actually enjoy is this Introduction to Quantum Computing. I know, it sounds so cutting-edge, right? Initially, it was intimidating, but the professor’s approach is to make it more about conceptual understanding than pure math. Of course, there is math—like linear algebra out the wazoo—but it’s interspersed with code examples in frameworks that simulate quantum circuits. We’re not actually building quantum computers or anything, but we’re modeling basic algorithms like Grover’s and Shor’s to see how they theoretically outperform classical methods. It’s mind-blowing stuff and has made me rethink how I approach problems.Then there’s my Capstone Project course, which, oh boy, is basically the sink-or-swim part of senior year. We have the entire semester to conceptualize, design, and build a software solution that solves some real problem. My group and I decided to work on a project that uses machine learning to analyze social media sentiment for better emergency response. Sounds fancy, but it essentially means reading a firehose of tweets or posts and analyzing them for words that might suggest a disaster or crisis. We’re building an interface that city officials—or maybe campus security—could theoretically use to see real-time alerts. It’s definitely pulling together everything I’ve learned as a CS major: database management, building an API, front-end interface, plus the ML pipeline. Because it’s a real, end-to-end solution, we’re also learning about project management and how to keep ourselves organized. One person on our team is the designated “Scrum Master,” so each week we have sprints, daily stand-ups, all that agile jazz. It’s a lot, but if we can pull it off, I’ll be super proud.Let’s see, what else can I share about my schedule? Oh, I’m also technically taking a humanities elective—Philosophy of Mind. It’s my last required non-CS elective, and I chose it because it ties back into AI in some interesting ways. We talk about consciousness, the concept of mind, and how that might apply to artificial intelligence. It’s a smaller class, so we do a lot of class discussions, and that’s a nice change of pace from all the coding in my other classes. Sometimes it’s nice to just sit back and analyze abstract ideas. It also helps me see the bigger picture—like the ethical implications of building AI systems that could one day mimic or simulate human thinking. Two weeks ago, I wrote a paper on whether strong AI could ever truly experience qualia—like the subjective experience of color or pain. It’s huge in the philosophy world, and it was such a trip to research. I think bridging technical knowledge with ethical considerations is important, so I’m grateful for that perspective.As for scheduling, I’m doing that typical college juggle. Mondays and Wednesdays are jam-packed. I start at 9:30 am with Advanced Algorithms, then I’ve got a short break to refuel before heading to my Distributed Systems lecture at 11:00. After lunch, I’ve got the Capstone meeting, which can be all over the place—sometimes it’s a lecture, sometimes it’s lab work, sometimes it’s project team time. Tuesdays and Thursdays are a bit lighter with just Quantum Computing in the morning and Game Design in the afternoon. Philosophy of Mind is on Thursday evenings, which can be brutal if I’m tired from the rest of the day. But hey, it’s senior year, and I gotta push through. Fridays, I keep open—no scheduled classes, but inevitably I’m working on assignments, group projects, or labs. I also do some undergrad research hours in a lab that’s focusing on data visualization for big scientific data sets. It’s interesting, but it definitely adds to the workload.Probably the biggest challenge this semester is balancing the group projects. Capstone alone can eat up a solid ten hours a week—more if you run into a big bug or if your model’s not training properly. Then the distributed systems project is another black hole for time. My group tries to meet at least twice a week. We also rely heavily on Slack or Discord to keep each other updated. But you know how it can go: coordinating five different people’s schedules is a mini-nightmare. Still, as stressful as it can be, it’s also exciting. This is going to be among my last chances to fully invest in a project that’s purely academic, purely about learning, without the pressures of an actual job environment.Overall, though, I’m having a blast. I used to dread the tougher CS classes because I was worried I wouldn’t keep up, but at this stage, I’ve gotten better at problem-solving and time management. I still pull the occasional late night—once in a while you just can’t avoid it, especially if something’s due the next day and you’re stuck debugging. But it’s never as scary as it once was. Being a senior has given me a sense of confidence; I know if I grind and keep my eye on the end goal, I’ll eventually figure things out. I guess that’s the biggest takeaway: after four years, you learn how to be resourceful, how to collaborate, and how to think critically. These classes are tough, no doubt, but they’re also super rewarding. Everything I’m doing now feels like it’s directly building toward my future career, and that’s a pretty great feeling.
